ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:44): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I think the "failure" (if there was one) had to do with choices about what went into strict that disagreed with what authors wanted to use and that worked in the browsers they cared about.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:44): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, maybe you should try to enforce your points by law
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:45): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I suppose target and iframe being the most important examples.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, they'll probably be familiar with that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:45): hides
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:45): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: as far as HTML tables and IE installed base are concerned, we have that kind of problem with HTML5
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:45): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: Didn't stop target from being a point of contention in html5 as well :)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:46): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Well of course not. Authors wanting to use doesn't make it a great idea.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:46): Whether it's a good idea or not doesn't mean much if it leads to scrapping your strict version by authors
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:47): depends on what the point of the versioning is
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:47): if the point of conformance is to get "good practice" but you can only get conformance by sanctioning "bad practice" that's a largely pointless exercise.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:48): fwiw, I'm not so much concerned about pushing an ideal of good practice
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:48): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: Not if allowing one bad practice means they fix a dozen others
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:48): I'm more interested in producing a tool that allows authors catch mistakes they didn't make
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:49): although Validator.nu does have political good practice aspects
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:49): what are "mistakes they didn't make"?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:49): didn't *intend* to make
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:50): how can you intend to make a mistake?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:50): E.g. if you're using a bad practice on purpose
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:50): is that good or bad? using a "bad practice" on purpose.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:50): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: if you use <embed> in HTML 4.01 on purpose, for example
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:51): that's not a "mistake". that's a conformance error.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:51): or an instance of deliberate non-conformance
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:52): validators can't really do much about instances of deliberate non-conformance
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:52): wonders what the point of this conversation is
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:52): the point for me, is increasing puzzlement about what conformance in HTML5 is, and its integrity as a single thing.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:53): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I guess the point on my side is that I don't believe as much in the wishful part of conformance as I think Hixie does
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:53): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: when it comes to removing "bad" legacy features from the conforming language

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:54): it seems to me the one bit of conformance everyone (?) would buy into is where you recommend features that work in lots of user agents over features that do the same thing but in fewer user agents.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:56): Hixie seems keen to use conformance to protect future extension points, which is a good idea, but of less widespread appeal.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:56): works for CSS
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:57): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: that's not what making align on td non-conforming is about, though
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:57): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: CSS has extension points built into the language.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:57): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I don't think CSS validation/conformance has been a particularly powerful force for authors.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:57): e.g. non-validating hacks, opacity, filter, vendor-specific extensions
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (23:58): with the last one built-in, but forbidden
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:58): I stopped paying attention to CSS validation when I couldn't configure the validator to grok Prince extensions
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:58): the validator should probably group extensions as a single error
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:59): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: this was the CSS validator running inside Oxygen
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:59): my impression has always been that quite a few authors do use the CSS validator, but that's anecdotical

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:00): Then there's conformance for trying to change authoring practices that could lead to errors, even when they in fact aren't errors that cause problems. e.g. &name in href.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:00): or spaces in URLs most of the time
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:00): While I'm glad of a tool to check that, I suspect that will reduce the amount of conformance considerably.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:01): e.g. lots of relatively conforming webpages fail to encode ampersands now
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:01): &name could cause a problem going forward
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:01): though that is somewhat avoided by requiring ; for new entities
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:01): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: yeah well I'm talking about &name= not &name;
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:02): and if one didn't require ; that would break _old_ content using &name=
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:02): of which there's plenty
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:02): &name is slightly suboptimal from a parser point of view
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:02): so an author might want to optimize that
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:03): yeah. they _might_.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:03): anyway, if you want &name to be conforming, you want <email/>

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:04): personally, I don't care whether it's conforming or not particularly (I just use &amp; ). I just think it's interesting as an aspect of the emerging picture of HTML5 conformance.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:05): ok

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:07): my guess (it's only a guess) is that there will be more websites failing conformance because of ampersand rules than would if HTML5 required alt (for example), since I see lots of websites with alt but that fail to encode ampersands

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:07): Flickr probably won't conform whatever the conformance rules are (alt isn't a "problem" for Flickr now, it just uses alt="" on the main photo page; it doesn't encode ampersands however).
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:08): given those speculations, I find much of the alt debate rather odd
